title.narrative: SJS - communication rights for victims of sexual violence in DRC
SJS - rätten till kommunikation för offer för sexuellt våld i DRK

description.narrative: Provision of information (healthcare, legal assistance, counselling) to victims of sexual violence. The project uses an anonymous telephone help service, based on the technology offered by Freedomfone.

Tillhandahållande av information (t.ex. hälsovård, juridisk hjälp, psykologiskt stöd) för kvinnor och flickor som fallit offer för sexuellt våld. Projektet använder sig av en hjälptelefon som tillhandahas av Freedomfone.

sector.narrative: Women’s rights organisations and movements, and government institutions

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: SJS has fulfilled the requirements as stipulated in the agreement with two exceptions: the final results framework and the latest management response are still missing despite numerous reminders.
The result framework however, has changed quite dramatically since project start and changes in the result framework has not always been documented/highlighted. Therefore, the register results related to the key intervention objectives does not give a clear picture of the overall achievements.
According to the final report, SJS is content with their work, especially when looking forward. The project has helped SJS to build their network, establish new local and international contacts, and experiences gained during the project will support future work. Now, SJS has a reputation as an organisation that successfully can use ICT-solutions to address local challenges. The Interactive Voice Response (IVR) technology used in this project, based on the Freedom Fone technology, will continue to operate and be publically accessible.
SJS’s theory of change was: victims get information about rights and services -> victims take action to address them. Inside this simple a -> b theory of change, lay a whole sequence of assumptions and conditions. SJS did a good work advocating against anti-sexual violence and to inform about rights and services through media and using the IVR. However, very few girls and women took the next step and visited a health centre, and on a state level we cannot see any change.
Some unexpected and anecdotal results of the project include an electrification programme of a semi-rural district outside Kinshasa run by Philips “in order to meet the safety needs expressed by the beneficiaries of our project during a basic awareness campaign”.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
